Black-throated Gray Warbler.notes: Striking black/white warbler, hops deliberately while gleaning insects.

Mountain Chickadee.notes: Widespread in western mountains, caches food and joins mixed flocks.

Western Tanager.notes: Males flash bright plumage; often perched high singing from treetops.

Lazuli Bunting.habitat: shrubby areas near open woodlands and streams
Lazuli Bunting.notes: Male’s blue plumage and song make them easy to spot along stream edges.

Cassin’s Finch.notes: Feeds heavily on pinecones, often in flocks with other finches.

Dusky Flycatcher.habitat: shrubby montane slopes and open forests
Dusky Flycatcher.notes: Typical ‘empid’ family behavior: perches and sally‑gleans insects.

Red‑naped Sapsucker.notes: Taps trees to feed on sap; creates holes used by many species.

Pine Siskin.notes: Flocks often invade feeders in winter after cone crop failures.

Hermit Thrush.notes: Melodic song echoes through forest understory at dawn.

Warbling Vireo.notes: Their continuous warbling makes them easy to hear, hard to see.

Yellow‑rumped Warbler.notes: One of the most common warblers in Idaho, easy to spot by rump.

MacGillivray's Warbler.notes: Often heard singing deep inside thickets, hard to see.

Chipping Sparrow.notes: Their dry trill song in trees signals territory in Idaho summers.

American Robin.notes: Classic spring songster; forages on lawns for worms.

Spotted Towhee.notes: Scratches leaf litter for seeds and insects with rapid hops.
